1400032717|5.0|Reading this is akin to falling down a rabbit hole, going to a place where all the markers of life are upside down.  Most people don't have Christopher Boone's skill at mathematics--but most readers of this book can find their way home after dark, and Christopher can't.  Is the novel an accurate depiction of autism?  I'm no expert so I don't know, but it feels right.  There's a bit of the Rain Man here, a little of Faulkner's idiot in \\"The Sound and the Fury,\\" and even a touch of Igatius Reilly from \\"A Confederacy of Dunces.\\"  Still, Christopher Boone is himself, unique, displaced, savant.  The most remarkable sequence in the novel involves a rather simple journey the narrator makes and the difficulties he initiates.    All in all, this is a book that will not be easy to forget, not for a long, long time.

B0001Z53AQ|2.0|I've read a lot of these reviews and I've learned this much......Amazon.com critics either get 1,000,000% behind an artist and hands them higher praise/stars than they really should be getting......or they do the exact opposite and just hate it for very childish reasons.  Very few people speak on the actual CD, rather they bash Eminem/D12 rather than telling the reader what makes the CD so bad.  I've seen reviews that gave this album 1 star because the reviewer prefers Esham instead.....or because he's a white man that hangs out with black men.....or because they're just die hard Ja Rule fans......or simply because he is who he is.  Then you have those that give this album 5 stars if for no other reason than the fact that Eminem is associated in some way (we have a word for these two extremes where I'm from: Haters or D*ck Riders).  Either way, none of these reviews are acurate and almost all of them fail to speak on the CD itself.  This album isn't anywhere close to 5 stars, but it's not deserving of a 1 star either.  \\"D12 World\\" is typical pop rap.  Anyone that bought this album in search of anything else was a fool to begin with.  The CD opens with Eminem spitting rhymes that would be ultra tight if they came from someone else, but Eminem (who has always been tight to me up until this point) has lost some steam and on this album it starts to show.  I'll speak about the other group members, but as we all know....they don't really matter.  Bizarre manages to bring the rating of this album down 2 stars all by himself.  If you want some decent rhymes from someone other than Eminem, look for Kon Artis or Proof.  Those two should break camp and start doing some solo stuff.  There are tracks produced by Kanye West and Lil' Jon (who supplied a VERY weak beat for the \\"40 Oz.\\" single), but for the most part, Eminem handles the production work and most of his beats sound the same.  Don't get me wrong, I like his beats, but they can get REALLY repetitive.  Most of the songs are VERY long and tend to be on the boring side.  A perfect example would be \\"Loyalty\\" feat. Obie Trice.  I love the beat and some of the lyrics are hot, but it's kind of long (5:54).  If you strip this entire album of all the beats and just listened to the lyrics, you'd actually have a pretty wack album on your hands. The beats aren't really that tight either.  And having Eminem perform every hook can be a bit tiresome.  But on a positive note, it's a progression from the last album in the sense that they're not trying to \\"out gross\\" or \\"out shock\\" each other on this album like they were doing on the last LP.  Overall, this is a middle of the road album.  Like I said before, it's typical pop rap.  If you expected something other than that, then the joke is on you.  Pop heads will love it, but heads like me that want skills and substance are better off searching the underground for quality hip hop because there is none on this album.  I would reccommend downloading this album instead of actually buying it though.  Come to think of it, I would NEVER reccommend buying any album that has Bizarre rapping on it.  He has NO SKILLS at all.  But that's just my opinion.  In my mind, if Eminem had never blown up like he did, you'd never hear from these guys (well maybe you'd hear from Proof and Kon Artis).  This is a perfect example of how having a famous homie can get you a record deal instead of landing a deal with actual skills.  Just ask Juelz Santana, him and the rest of the Dip Set are in the same boat.are VERY long and tend to be on the boring side.  A perfect example would be \\"Loyalty\\" feat. Obie Trice. B00005JMAH|4.0|\\"Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban\\" succeeds on many notes but fails to execute the more important elements of the story. But first I'll note the positives, because although this movie is flawed, it still had some GREAT stuff. <br /> <br />Briefly, the famous wizard Harry Potter is about to start his third year at Hogwarts School. But a fierce dark wizard Sirius Black has done the impossible - escaped from Azkaban Prison. Everybody's lives - especially Harry's are in danger. This film is the third chapter in a series of films based on the novels by J.K Rowling. <br /> <br />Firstly the music, which is always a great listen has gotten even more magical. There's an original song called \\"Double Trouble\\" which is very clever and definately transports you into the world of wands.  <br /> <br />Secondly, the special effects are also great. Two particularly good installments are the Dementors (horrifying ghostly spirits) and Buckbeak the Hippogriff (a half eagle, half horse creature). The overall special effects were good. Although it doesn't come close to \\"Lord of the Rings\\" standard, they were certainly better than the last two films' visual effects.  <br /> <br />Thirdly, the young actors (including Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson) put in a much more passionate performance playing our heros Harry, Ron and Herminone. I also loved seeing some of the great actors back in the robes including Maggie Smith, Alan Rickman, Emma Thompson and Dawn French (to name a few). <br /> <br />But although the technical aspects of the film were above average, the actual film was a huge disappointment for me, and I'm sure for millions of other Harry Potter fans.  <br /> <br />You see, the attitude of the film was completly mis-initerpretted and was more of a comedy bash and less of a movie about good versus evil. Yes, Rowling's original stories are very humourous and ingeniously witty, but there is another serious and haunting side of the books that was too vague for my taste. The emotional side of the film was overpowered by unnessecary wise-cracking. Like I mentioned before, I am all for humour, but there was simply too much of it for the motive of the storyline. It's a story of horror, of evil, of heartbreak - all of which were very poorly conveyed and I was not impressed. <br /> <br />Secondly, was the wussiness of the wizard jock Draco Malfoy (Tom Felton). Malfoy is not a clutz! He is a sinister, cunning and spiteful teenager. Again, this important element of Rowling's stories were overwhelmed by silly humour. <br /> <br />And finally was the ending of the film. While the opening was brilliant, the ending is a repulsive close-up still of Harry's wind-pulled face as he flies his broomstick, and just ends the entire film on a pointless note. Another minor issue was Hogwarts' sudden change of location but I wasn't really fussed about that. <br /> <br />Maybe I'm a little bit critical, but as a passionate Harry Potter reader, I was really unimpressed by how this film turned out. The books get substantially darker as you move through and that darkness simply wasn't outstanding.  <br /> <br />But as I stressed earlier, this IS a pretty good film. The acting, music and visual effects really were very well done. Although I didn't appreciate the  overhumour, I DID enjoy some of the fresh jokes and had particularly loved Ron's facial expressions (whoes character WAS fairly faithful to the novels).  <br /> <br />I really hope the fourth film is a bit more faithful to its novel, because it is a MUCH darker story. Nevertheless, I am lookng forward to its release! :) <br /> <br />So in conclusion I enjoyed this film alot apart from those couple major flaws. I hope this review is helpful and shows you not only the good sides, but also the aspects that could have been improved. It was a good effort, alot of fun, but not quite in the right spirit of things.

B00005JN2X|5.0|From my point of view, the premise seemed to be very repetitive and potentially boring, but that all changed on August 12, when I went to see this on a rainy day. Don't get me wrong - the plot does involve five murders by hitman Tom Cruise, playing Vincent, who is driven around by Jamie Foxx, playing Max, but there is a lot more to it than that.  <br /> <br />The dialogue is outstanding. Foxx, brilliantly cast, is funny at times, but he doesn't come off as trying too hard to be funny, which is what Will Smith is often guilty of. Cruise, playing a villain for once, shows his dark side and turns in a more than convincing performance. This movie, like other Michael Mann movies, relies on good dialogue. There are extended scenes of just talking, but they are so well-written that you don't even notice. A lesser director would have deleted scenes in favor of the more action-packed ones. Now, there is a lot of action and violence, but it never really gets carried away, and it never is without a point. Vincent tries to convince Max that what he is doing isn't all bad, even though it is murder. This is crucial because it shows the character development. <br /> <br />Also of note, the scenery and cinematography of South Central Los Angeles is beautiful. The more violent scenes are incredibly real, on the same level of being real that Saving Private Ryan was on. It may have just been because I was in a theater, but the gunshots sounded real, and the way Tom Cruise handled himself as a marksman made him look like a real hitman. That's something that you can't train for. You either have it or you don't. <br /> <br />And, there were cops in this movie that were chasing after the cab, but only for a very brief part of the movie, so that it didn't end up being like another one of those cat and mouse movies that I grow quite tired of. Yet, at the same time, there still are lot of thrilling action sequences. This truly is one of the best movies that I ever saw.

Piece of Mind is the second appearance by classic vocalist Bruce Dickinson, and it was concieved on the heels of their international breakthrough \\"The Number of the Beast\\".  <br /> <br />\\"Where Eagles Dare\\" opens the album with a bang, a tense, increadibly fast slab of METAL with a great hook. \\"Revelations\\" is similar to the previous album's \\"Children of the Damned\\", but more complete. The third track is the hit single \\"Flight of Icarus\\", a wonderful song with a wonderful chorus, and lyrics about the ancient myth. After it is the pumping, fist-in-the-air anthem \\"Die With Your Boots On\\" (Check out the cover by power metal band Sonata Arctica, it is even BETTER), followed by the second single, the galloping war tale \\"The Trooper\\", a classic Maiden song, which has some great guitar work. While the past songs have all been kickass Maiden rock, the quality starts to decline from here (something which would become a bad habit later on, during the 90s). \\"Still Life\\" holds it's own, it's similar to something from their \\"Killers\\" album, but not wuite up to par to the previous songs. \\"Quest For Fire\\" and \\"Sun & Steel\\" are both filler tracks, not really much to either, the latter is much better but still not very good. The closer \\"To Tame a Land\\" is based on the classic novel Dune, and its on par with the beggining songs in the album, an intelligent epic with increadible guitar pieces. <br /> <br />\\"Piece of Mind\\" suffers as the only of the first 7 Maiden albums that has obvious filler, and also because it followed the previous year's smash hit and came before 1984's Masterpiece \\"Powerslave\\". Piece of Mind is a lower point from either album, and it is perhaps the, let's say, least-best of the first 7. However, the first 5 pieces and the closer alone make it worthwhile for fan of the band, as all 6 songs are someof Maiden's BEST.  <br /> <br />Where Eagles Dare- 10/10 <br />Revelations- 9/10 <br />Flight of Icarus- 10/10 <br />Die With Your Boots On- 9.5/10 <br />The Trooper- 10/10 <br />Still Life- 8/10 <br />Quest For Fire- 5/10 <br />Sun And Steel 6.5/10 <br />To Tame a Land- 9.5/10
B000286S8S|2.0|The biggest thing I noticed from listening to this album is that it sounds like two different bands. B000063DI9|5.0|Seventh Son of a Seventh Son was the last in a line of virtually universally aclaimed Albums that Iron Maiden churned out throughout the 80s. It was the last with the Classic Line-Up (Adrian Smith departed shortly after because of creative differences) and their last album of the Golden Decade for Metal; the 1980s. Seventh Son continued the path first explored on the previous album, 1986's \\"Somewhere in Time\\", which introduced heavy use of synths into the usual Maiden formula with succesful results. SSOASS improves on S.I.T.'s weaknesses by turning up the guitar sound that was downsized in said album. SSOASS was also something very new lyrics-wise, being the first solid Maiden concept album, and the story was made specifically for the album. It deals with a titanic struggle between good and evil revolving around the prophetic seventh son, the story's protagonist, who can either bring about the salvation of his people or their ultimate doom. <br /> <br />The album kicks off with an atmosphere-setting passage, just Bruce reciting a few lines accompanied by an acoustic guitar, before the adrenaline-filled opener \\"Moonchild\\" blasts out in full, synth-ridden glory. Like most songs on the album, Moonchild is far different from most other Maiden songs to date. Following \\"Moonchild\\" is the POWER Ballad \\"Infinite Dreams\\", a fan favourite. The next two cuts were the more famous singles: \\"Can I Play With Madness?\\", a synth-driven Pop song unlike anything Maiden has composed, and the more Rock N Roll \\"The Evil That Men Do\\", a fast, hard song that displays an increadible hook and poetic lyrics (Plus one of the best opening lines Maiden have penned: \\"Love is a Razor/And I Walk the Line on that Silver Blade\\"). They switch gears for the next song, the masterful Epic Title Track, sporting increadible musical passages and lyrical wonders. \\"Prophecy\\" is another different song, more of a \\"breather\\" after the last 3 songs (while still being pretty fast), with some extremely nice guitarmelodies. The last two songs are again, plain awesome Maiden. \\"The Clairvoyant\\" has a defiant tone and increadible bass-playing from Mr. Harris. \\"Only the Good Die Young\\" is another fast one, and while more \\"common\\" than the rest of the songs, it (like CLairvoyant) sports increadible lyrical insight and even a BASS SOLO from Steve. At the end of the song, th same lyrical passage from the beggining begins again, just Bruce and the acoustic. The cycle begins again.  <br /> <br />Seventh Son of a Seventh Son is the major peak in Maiden's career as it displays genius not only in its amazing instrumentation, but also because of it's lyrical value, and overall structures of every song. It's a concept album made up of songs that could work just as easily by themselves, not to mention nearly all the songs are distinct from any other Maiden era, all display something new that they hadn't tried before, or perfected in this release.  <br /> <br />This album is a must-have for Iron Maiden fans, as one of their most complete and successful. It's not only a cornerstone in Maiden career, but a cornerstone for Progressive Metal and conceptual albums as well, not to mention all of 80s Rock. It is simply fantastic. <br /> <br />Moonchild- 9.5/10 <br />Infinite Dreams- 9/10 <br />Can I Play With Madness?- 10/10 <br />The Evil That Men Do- 10/10 <br />Seventh Son of a Seventh Son- 9.5/10 <br />Prophecy- 8.5/10 <br />The Clairvoyant- 10/10 <br />Only the Good Die Young- 10/10
B00024BHTC|1.0|Heard it all before.  Opera and Metal, yawn yawn yawn.  You'd think some of these reviewers had just been born.... This album is crap.  Luckily we needed a new frisbe, so thank you Nightwish.
B000063DHL|5.0|For their 6th release, Maiden opted to expand their musical soundscape with synthesizers, which were actually all the rage in the 80s. The idea made many fans feared an over-commercialization of their sound; that the band was selling out. 1986's \\"Somewhere in Time\\" proved the fears wrong, and the merging between true Heavy Metal and synthesizers was a great success.  <br /> <br />The first song and title track \\"Cought Somewhere in Time\\" was a powerful 7- minute Epic that serves to sum up the album. Next is the hit single, and one of my favourites, \\"Wasted Years\\" a melancholic Adrian Smith-penned power ballad. \\"Sea of Madness\\" is a very heavy song, probably the heaviest in the album. Following it is the \\"short\\" epic Heaven Can Wait, a concert favourite and shout-along anthem that will stay in your head for days. \\"Lonliness of the Long Distance Runner\\" is an obvious throw-back at 70s-Prog-Rock Gods Yes's \\"Long Distance Runaround\\". While the lyrics are very weak, the upbeat solo, great intro and solid chorus save the song. The album's other single \\"Stranger in a Strange Land\\" is another slow melancholic song, but much heavier than Wasted Years and just as intense. \\"De Ja Vu\\" is a light, fast rocker of the album, good concept too and great intro. Like nearly all Maiden Closers, the last song on this album is the epic \\"Alexander The Great\\", a powerful finish to the album, displaying spoken word intros and a marital-pace clean-guitar intro before kicking into the historical biographic Epic. <br /> <br />The production is very different from any other, and the guitars are pushed back and very fuzzy, yet the synths don't take over the sound either, while Bruce also sounds distant. If it doesn't read well, don't worry, the effect makes for a very interest sound that is increadibly \\"epic\\" and surprisingly fresh. The sound would be similar in the next album, but not as drastically different. <br /> <br />While Somewhere in Time does not surpass the increadible and straight-forward \\"Powerslave\\" nor it's own synth-laden follow-up \\"Seventh Son of a Seventh Son\\", it is nonetheless one of the quintessential Maiden releases that features many great songs plus a side to Maiden that is different from any other of their albums. <br /> <br />Caught Somewhere in Time- 10/10 <br />Wasted Years- 10/10 <br />Sea of Madness- 8.5/10 <br />Heaven Can Wait- 10/10 <br />Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner- 9/10 <br />Stranger in a Strange Land- 9/10 <br />De Ja Vu- 9/10 <br />Alexander the Great- 8.5/10
B0001Z52RU|4.0|The idea of traveling through time has been a staple of science fiction since H.G. Wells's time. Who wouldn't want to go back and be a part of history in the making or altering those situations that led to the more horrific events of the past?<br /><br />Ashton Kutcher stars as a young man that makes several life-changing \\"treks\\" to his past, only to discover that each one brings about an \\"alteration\\" more devastating than the next. B0002DB50E|5.0|This was the film that opened up the very strange but fascinating world of David Cronenberg to me.  I have seen nearly all his films since then, and this remains one of his boldest and his best.   <br /> <br />It is a very difficult film to describe, since it uses the now familar Cronenberg trick of showing us everything from the point of view of one unreliable character.  Max Renn owns a sleazy cable channel and is looking for the next big thing - and stumbles across Videodrome which may (or may not) cross the line into snuff film. <br /> <br />From this rather unappetizing plot device, Cronenberg goes off in a number of directions.  The movie initially did not get good reviews and I think people could not see what Cronenberg was really doing here.  He is criticizing, often with dark comedy, our media saturated world, how the media can program us just as we can program a VCR, and how the line between reality and \\"media reality\\" can quickly be blurred.  But it is a horror film, complete with conspiracy theory and a horrific medical by-product to give the film a very dark undertone. <br /> <br />There are some jaw dropping visuals here, from breathing VCR tapes to melting body parts.  Unlike many of his fellow horror directors, I never felt Cronenberg gives us pure shock effects - he always uses his gore as symbolism or as punctuation to tell us we have hit a major segment of his film. Let me add Cronenberg got strong performances from the reliable James Woods and to everyone's surprise Deborah Harry from the rock group Blondie.  <br /> <br />OK, some of the character names are a little too cutesy, and who knows what in the end is actually happening here at times.  But the film has not lost its ability to shock and be thought provoking.  Indeed, in a time of Reality TV, 100 plus cable channels, and non stop 24 hour political spin cycles, Videodrome seems ahead of its time and almost prophetic in places.

B00003CXXP|3.0|Spielberg's movie is eventually rather slow and convoluted after a promising start. It becomes a tad pretentious, sends mixed messages and fails to hang together as a coherent vision. Throw in the typical Spielbergian tendency to sentimentalism, and you end up with a fairly uneven film. <br /> <br />It will disappoint those who expected a pacey action-thriller, but as a futuristic fantasy/fairy-tale variation of Pinocchio, it certainly maintains a genuine charm and sense of enchantment. B000066NW0|4.0|Yes everyone, Avril Lavigne sings pop music. No need to continue writing \\"reviews\\" trying to educate us conformist, moronic zombies. Believe me, we know already. Everyone knows. Referring to her as a poseur? Well that doesn't make much sense, and just make you sound unintelligent. As far as I recall, the closest she's come to claiming herself as a \\"punk\\" was revealing that she told record executives that she wanted to \\"rock out\\" a bit on her album when they asked her to sing \\"Celine Dion-type\\" songs. So technically, if she were to be a self-proclaimed anything, she would be a self-proclaimed rocker, not a self-proclaimed punk. Also, since the punk accusations arose, she's repeatedly stated in interviews that, in fact, she doesn't think of herself as punk, pop, rock, or any other specific genre. Rather, she's claimed to be nothing more or less than herself.  <br /> <br />'Let Go' isn't amazing, but it's good for a debut. The lyrics are a little \\"high school\\", and the music is simple. But the hooks are catchy, and just try getting the choruses out of your head. This is definitely an album to check out, although don't expect to be blown away. Judging from this album, Avril Lavigne is certainly an artist to watch. I expect she'll get better with age. She has a fantastic, unique voice, in future projects if she can improve on her lyrics, and come up with more original melodies, I suspect she'll be a force to be reckoned with. <br /> <br />The album starts out on a strong note with 'Losing Grip'. This is an up-beat, catchy track. The most rock-influenced song on this pop album, Avril sings about how angry she is with someone after they left her all alone in a place where she felt uncomfortable, scared and which she was unfamiliar with. 'Complicated' would be a good second track if it hadn't been so over-played. Curse Canadian Content and it's silly 35% requirement. It forces us all to listen to every new Avril Lavigne, Sarah McLachlan, or Barenaked Ladies song a million times a day. I blame CanCon for altering 'Complicated' from a fun, infectious single that I actually quite liked the first million-or-so times I heard it, into a painfully annoying track that I always seem to skip. The third track is 'Sk8er Boi', this is the worst song on the album. The first couple of times I listened to it, I really liked it, but upon further attention, it became average, at best. It's a very juvenile song about a girl who refuses to go out with a, you guessed it, \\"sk8er boi\\", then regrets it when he grows up to become a rock star.  <br /> <br />'I'm With You' is among the best on the album. It's the first ballad on 'Let Go', and one of my personal favourite songs on it. Upon listening to the ultra-simple lyrics \\"Isn't anyone trying to find me/Won't somebody come take me home\\" I had no choice but to fall in love with this track. The fifth track, 'Mobile', brings us back to the faster songs on the album. It's about how Avril feels her life is constantly changing. She refers to herself as a \\"mobile\\" because she frequently feels that she's \\"spinning 'round with mixed feelings\\". 'Unwanted' is a very anger-driven song. With prolonged notes and music slightly bordering on dark and melodic (in comparison to the rest of the album), it's one of the stand out tracks. The seventh track is the sweet, somewhat hopeless 'Tomorrow'. It's the second slow song on 'Let Go', and Avril's voice sounds exquisitely innocent, yet grown-up on it. On 'Anything But Ordinary', Avril reveals her dreams of leading a life distinct from the norm. Stating all the weird things she does, such as laughing herself to sleep and driving fast \\"just to feel the danger\\".  <br /> <br />I absolutely love the up-beat 'Things I'll Never Say'. Somehow it finds a way to incorporate all the different emotions teenagers can feel around the guy or girl they have feelings for. Lyrically, Avril wishes she could tell things to her \\"crush\\" that she knows she could never say. 'My World' could almost bedescribed as Avril's theme song, if that makes sense. In the up-tempo, pop track, Avril tells all who'll listen just what her life growing up was like in a small town (Napanee, Ontario). The eleventh song on 'Let Go' is 'Nobody's Fool'. Lyrically, Avril refuses to let anyone change her, stating, \\"If you're trying to turn me into someone else/It's easy to see that I'm not down with that/I'm not nobody's fool\\". 'Too Much To Ask' is a great, slower song about being let down by someone. Avril belts out lyrics about being annoyed with somebody who always feels sorry for himself and refuses to smile or laugh. The album ends on a sweet note with 'Naked'. It's about being so comfortable around someone that she feels as though she's naked, but doesn't seem to mind. It refers to trust and being able to be yourself. <br /> <br />All-in-all, 'Let Go' is a strong pop debut. I'd recommend checking it out if you're a fan of Michelle Branch, Chantal Kreviazuk, or Liz Phair. Avril doesn't quite have the genius song-writing skills just yet, but I'm guessing that by her third album, she'll have gained a ton of experience, and be unstoppable. <br /> <br />THE FINAL VERDICT: 80%

1594200106|4.0|The story is a classic whodunit with some clever touches and twists thrown in.  The author starts out as if he meant to write a major work of literature.  He tries very hard and, for a while, succeeds. The imaginative plot, florid language and moody atmosphere hooks the reader early.  Unfortunately, the author runs out of steam about half way through.  This is not to say that the story degenerates.  The pace continues and the book remains a good read to the very end.  But the nature of the work changes; it turns into a popular \\"novela\\" with all the expected elements: love, sex, baudy humor, violence, etc.  One even finds oneself reading faster. Each reader can decide which half s/he prefers.  I would have gladly exchanged the last 100 pages for a shorter, tighter story in the opening style of the work.  It coulda been a contender!

B00009UW0N|5.0|Halloween is still one of my favorite movies and an outstanding low-budget (even for its day) production.  I first saw the movie on a free promotional week of HBO on Halloween Night, 1979.  I had seen the 1st edition paperback displaying a sheet covered figure with the jack-o-lantern head on both covers.  It intrigued me immensely but I was \\"too young\\" to read \\"murder books.\\"  I was about 12 years old.  So when my parents went to sleep for the night I turned off the lights, ate my trick-or-treat candy, and watched the forbidden R-rated Halloween on our 25\\" color console.  And that, I think, is the whole appeal of Halloween to the die-hard fans of today: we remember what USED to scare us.  Why was it such a powerful production?  Because it was so down-to-earth and real; so real, in fact, that when the movie ended I found myself wondering whether or not a human being could be so seriously injured that many times and then get up and walk away.  I pondered whether any of the wounds the killer received until the finale actually were fatal.  Silly lines or not, the characters were believable.  I knew girls like that (the post-hippi generation was a strange one) and lived in a similar neighborhood.  I could readily identify with the falling leaves and rain, the decorations on the houses, huge dark lawns, etc.  Halloween sparked such a mass of rip-offs and gore slashers that the idea of what true horror was shifted dramatically from that which could almost happen to that which is absolutley impossible and unbeleivable.  I suspect that the only people Halloween could still stir up are pre-teen adolescents who have never witnessed horror or viloence in films...(these days?)...ain't gonna happen.<br /><br />For those of you who have never watched Halloween the most modern film I can compare it to is The Ring.  It built its horror more on suspense and the expectation of the unexpected.  It also gave very limited and brief glimpses of the stalker, thus building viewer apprehension.  The soundtrack is repetitious and monotonous, but quite invoking.  It sucked us right into the film with the characters; we were one of the unsuspecting teens.<br /><br />Halloween is more a film for history buffs and is really no good at all for scaring anyone these days.  But it is a great movie to share with friends during the Halloween season, and I highly recommend buying it, either in the H25 special edition, original edition, or extended theatrical original (with the 1980 made-for-television scenes) thrown in/my personal favorite.  It is a highly enjoyable and well produced film, but best suited to share shelf-space with Psycho, Amelie, Ran, Lillies of the Field, The King and I, and other timeless classics, rather than with later horror flicks.<br /><br />The quality of this disc will not disappoint you.  If you are a fan of other Halloween films you will see a dramatic but refreshing difference.  If you have never seen it and are just curious, then by all means rent it first and don't expect anything more than a simply entertaining movie.  It's dated and somewhat awkward but not cheesy (well...maybe once or twice, but it passes quickly).  I have several versions and will continue watching and sharing them, especially on Halloween.sion.  The soundtrack is repetitious and monotonous, but quite invoking.  It sucked us right into the film with the characters; we were one of the unsuspecting teens.  <br /> <br />Halloween is more a film for history buffs and is really no good at all for scaring anyone these days.  But it is a great movie to share with friends during the Halloween season, and I highly recommend buying it, either in the H25 special edition, original edition, or extended theatrical original (with the 1980 made-for-television scenes) thrown in/my personal favorite.  It is a highly enjoyable and well produced film, but best suited to share shelf-space with Psycho, Amelie, Ran, Lillies of the Field, The King and I, and other timeless classics, rather than with later horror flicks. <br /> <br />The quality of this disc will not disappoint you. B00006AFUR|4.0|It all started when the song \\"Capricorn\\" came up on RockNews' list of upcoming rock songs.  The names of both the band and the song conjured up the sounds of 311, Sublime and other punk/ska bands.  I like both of the aforementioned bands, but not enough to actually look for other bands with a similar sound.  But I'm sure I had no other things to do, so I gave the song a shot, despite these less-than-promising preconceptions.<br /><br />To my fortune, and grateful surprise, I was very, very wrong.<br /><br />30 Seconds to Mars is not like 311 and less like Sublime.  This band is furious, and has a unique power that relies less on speed and more on vocal and melodic depth.  Jared Leto's screaming (yet very listenable) vocals, gripping and powerful, seem to fit perfectly with the pounding guitars and relentless drums.  Songs like \\"Buddha for Mary\\" and \\"Oblivion\\" seem to have a bottomless fountain of power.  Yes, these guys don't stop.  While they can have spacey interludes in between furious choruses, the songs do seem to flow.  No, there's no soft song as most bands tend to have (Disturbed's \\"Darkness\\", Cold's \\"Bleed\\" and Stone Sour's \\"Bother\\"), but this shouldn't discourage you from listening to this band.<br /><br />Their depth (I don't know it it's produced by the guitar sounds, or the combination of everything) is a sound that I can't find in any other band.  Maybe if the Offspring were ever to leave punk rock behind and adopt a nu-metal sound, this is what they'd sound like.  If you're ever in the mood to pound your head into the wall, while at the same time enjoying a band for their musical craftsmanship, you shouldn't hesitate to listen to these guys.  Both the pace at which the songs unravel and the fury with which they are delivered are factors that should not be overlooked.  Happy listening.<br /><br />Recommendations: \\"Capricorn\\", \\"Oblivion\\", \\"Buddha for Mary\\", \\"End of the Beginning\\"

0790730960|4.0|Batman Returns is a perfect film to watch during the holiday season as the winter/Xmas atmosphere that Burton creates for Gotham City is wonderful. It's weird that Warner decided to release this as a summer film. It doesn't fit.<br /><br />But what's even weirder, when you consider the content of this film, is that it was aimed at families. An upper-class family throws their mutant baby down the sewer, a socio-phobic billionaire dresses up in leather as a flying rodent, a lonely secretary has a mental breakdown and dresses up in leather as a feline, and said grown-up mutant baby freak runs for political office. Not to mention the S&M subtext that Tim Burton somehow managed to get away with. His eccentric visual style fits this film best, and is the height of his career, IMO.<br /><br />This and the Dark Knight are the only true live-action incarnations of the comic-book character. True, Batman Returns is not as grown-up and serious as the Dark Knight, but it's a helluva lot atmospheric, and I just prefer the oddball character development here than in TDK. I rate them both equally, but scoring points on different levels.<br /><br />Darker and more violent than the first movie, the sense of Gothic pathos reaches a new high. I was quite keen on Michael Keaton as Bruce Wayne (don't even get me started on George Clooney!), he displayed the right balance of weirdo loner and cool crime fighter. Michelle Pfieffer is great as Catwoman (much sexier and more 'realistically' cat-like), she wears that leather outfit better than Halle Berry. And Danny DeVito was so convincing as the Penguin that his scenes become disturbing to watch. Special mention must be made of Christopher Walken, who is brilliant as the spooky Max Shreck (if you think you recognize Chip Shrek it's none other than a very young Leatherface/Butterfinger).<br /><br />Danny Elfman's score is also even better than it was first time round. His powerful and engaging themes are way better than the dross that followed in the later Schumacher movies. This movie is the Batman phenomenon at its Zenith. Forget the following sequels and stick to the animated series after this. Christopher Nolan brought integrity back to the series, but before Schumacher destroyed it, Burton gave the original series integrity too.<br /><br />A great Xmas film, and my favorite Batman adventure.<br /><br />The Blu Ray looks amazing in 1080p 1.85:1 widescreen, with bold, deep blacks and near perfect colors. Plenty of extras too.This movie is the Batman phenomenon at its Zenith. Forget the following sequels and stick to the animated series after this. B000002H97|5.0|This is an excellent album, one of the greatest of the Rock/Metal genre and definitely the greatest of this band's achievements.  They displayed very good lyrical, as well as musical composition: hard hitting metal and thought provoking lyrics.  One thing I appreciated about the lyrics is that the intense negativity so prevalent on their other albums was not so present on this one.   <br />      <br />     This band has definitely put their fingerprint in music history.  Although, I do have one comment to make about the band in general: they are extremely overrated.  NO BAND deserves a day or an hour dedicated solely to them on every radio station in the country.  Metallica is by no means the most technically capable band, nor is their music in the slightest way comparable to Beethoven.   There are subtle classical influences weaved into their songs, yes, but to compare their compositions to Beethoven is a far cry from reality.  Anyone who would rate Metallica by comparison with Beethoven has obviously not listened with an educated ear to the music of Beethoven, or any other great classical composer for that matter. <br /> <br />     I felt this album deserved five stars; nevertheless, there are more technically skilled bands in the Rock/Metal genre.  Likewise, there are bands that have invented a more original sound than Metallica.  Due to advertising, (the Metallica day and hour on every radio station in the world), I am frequently irritated when I endeavor to introduce a new and talented band to the average radio listener and like an automated machine, programmed by the industry, they spew: \\"That sounds like Metallica!\\" at the fist hint of a heavy riff.   <br /> <br />     For what it's worth, my humble opinion of Metallica as a band is: great; and greatly overrated.  For those who would like to hear a Metal composition that can be remotely compared to Beethoven try: Symphony X: The Odyssey.   <br />

B0002IU988|5.0|I've read a few of the reviews already posted, and in some ways I'll have to disagree... Myles Kennedy has NO problem keeping up with Tremonti and company. Anyone saying that is stricktly comparing his style to that of Scott Stapp. These guys are opposite sides of the world. Stapp couldn't handle the change in lifestyle that success brought, it changed him, and you could hear it in his vocalizations and inflections as time went on in Creeds catalog. Myles already has that 'Rock Star' (..sorry Myles, couldn't help that one) vibe about him, he's comfortable in his skin, and with his place in the band. Fearless is how it sounds to me, he's not letting the shadow of Creed intimidate his  performance. The one thing that DID jump roght out at me is that his vocal style very closely resembles that of Ian Thornley of Big Wreck(think \\"The Oaf\\") <br />  Tremonti's guitar has never been better, to my ears. He's always had the shredder gene in him, but until now, kept it subdued. But he's released it with the one thing most shredders completely lose sight of, taste and songmanship. He's definately letting his metal roots show a LOT more than he ever could in Creed. <br />  The rhythm section is exactly what it should be: hard, heavy, and ROCK solid. Brian Marshall's switch to a 5-string bass has added a noticable depth and life to the music, more open than in the past, and Scott Phillips is, like his guitar-slinging bandmate Tremonti, at the top of his game. Neither overplaying, nor lacking in his duties, he makes a strong foundation for Alter Bridge to stand on. <br />  Far from a first trip to the studio for any member of the band, there's still a freshness to the music. Congradulations to Alter Bridge for taking what could have easily been 'Creed:Part 2' and making the music stand and shine on the strength of it's own merit. This is an entirely new unit, with new ideas of how the music should sound.   <br />

I don't understand at all why that was included. <br /> <br />However . . . there is a previously unreleased song here called \\"You Know You're Right,\\" and that one song makes the CD worth buying if you're a fairly hardcore Nirvana fan. It's one of their best songs, utilizing their trademark (though ripped off from the Pixies) soft-verse-loud-chorus format in an anguished-sounding way that absolutely exhilarates the listener. It's a truly great song, and worth the CD. I wouldn't recommend the CD to a first-time Nirvana listener; I would suggest \\"Nevermind\\" and \\"In Utero\\" first because they give a much better picture of what Nirvanawas about. Then buy \\"Nirvana.\\" Thing is, if you're more of a casual fan, you can download \\"You Know You're Right\\" and put it on a much better mix than this. <br /> <br />Come to think of it, I wish that's what I had done.

B00003CXB2|5.0|Lawrence of Arabia is one of the finest films ever made.  It lacks a happy ending, but it is one of the most beautiful, sweeping, romantic, thought-provoking, historically accurate, and realistic epics ever made.  If you can believe Lawrence was Peter O'Toole's first film, and that he was nominated for a Best Actor Oscar and DIDN'T GET IT - then you will have an idea of the sad feeling you have at the end. David Lean directed this film, five years after he directed the Bridge on the River Kwai.  Lawrence's cinematography and music are sublime.  There are many, many very good actors in minor roles.<br /><br />The film tells the true story of T.E. Lawrence, a British officer who was stationed in the Middle East during WWI.  Lawrence donned sheik's robes and led fractious nomadic tribes in a successful revolt against the Turks.  The unusual army destroyed Turkish rail lines and drove them out of their stronghold in Akaba, paving the way for the British army to come in.<br /><br />Lawrence was enchanted by the harsh simplicity of the desert, and had a genuine love and respect for the desert tribes.  He wanted the desert to belong to the Arabs, but constant warring among tribes and imperialist intervention crushed his dream.  He returned to England disillusioned and bitter.  For more information, Lawrence's book \\"Seven Pillars of Wisdom,\\" published in 1922.  Seven Pillars details his experiences in the desert with the nomadic warriors, and the revolt.  David Lean, the film's director, based the film almost entirely on this book.<br /><br />In the film, O'Toole plays the strange and unique Lawrence perfectly.  O'Toole's intense blue, searching eyes, his handsomeness and his golden hair lend to create and immortalize the mythic figure of this warrior-poet.  One thing you know right away is that they broke the mold when they made Lawrence.  O'Toole seems lost in the British military compound, and comes alive in the punishing environment of the desert.  His brave and courageous acts leads a sheik to become his friends.  Omar Sharif plays Ali. His tribe follows Lawrence through \\"the sun's anvil\\" on a risky mission to add a band of brigands to their army.  The leader of the tribe of brigands, Auda, is played by Anthony Quinn.<br /><br />The scenes up until Lawrence's capture and abuse by Turks are glorious and inspiring.  El Aurents, as the nomads call him, is the Braveheart of the Desert.  But as in Braveheart, as in war, things cannot always end as they begin.  Herein lies the heartache of war.  A scene where Lawrence loses his mind and takes it out on bedraggled injured Turks is incredibly painful to watch, considering all that has come before.<br /><br />Sharif is so passionate, and an incredible actor.  He is Lawrence's sole support and it is painful to watch his grief as his friend slips into depression and madness.  Like O'Toole, he too had an Oscar snatched out of his hand.ik to become his friends.  Omar Sharif plays Ali. His tribe follows Lawrence through \\"the sun's anvil\\" on a risky mission to add a band of brigands to their army.  The leader of the tribe of brigands, Auda, is played by Anthony Quinn. But as in Braveheart, as in war, things cannot always end as they begin.  Herein lies the heartache of war. Sharif is so passionate, and an incredible actor.  He is Lawrence's sole support and it is painful to watch his grief as his friend slips into depression and madness.  Like O'Toole, he too had an Oscar snatched out of his hand.

0802130208|5.0|This is a work of genius. At some level Confederacy of Dunces is a comedy, but its so unbelievably creative and so well written that it goes well beyond that. A great book, timeless, in the tradition of Cervantes, clearly something that will be read for a long, long time. <br /> <br />The cohesiveness of the work makes it difficult to highlight partcular elements that stood out. There are impassioned explorations of character throughout - the central protaganist is at the same time too absurd to be real, and too completely concieved to be fiction. And there is a clockwork symmetry to the plot that comes together seamlessly and often hilarously at unexpected points. But perhaps the most striking thing I was left with was an affection for Igancious, the central character of the book. He's paranoid, manipulative, self-centered, ugly and unpleasant to all, and at the same time a completely sympathetic character. I'm not sure what magic Toole used to pull this off, but it is without question, beautifully done. <br /> <br /> <br />There's a lot made of this being a New Orleans book, but the geography of the city seemed entirely secondary to the immediate environments it portrays - the shabby homes, the seedy bars, the dank bus station bathrooms, were much more real to me than the descriptions of the French Quarter. <br /> <br />There were a few rough patches in the last few chapters, where the dialogue becomes a little disjointed. It seemed a bit less cleanly edited than the rest of the book. It left the feeling for me that maybe Toole wasn't fully finished with it, that maybe he had a tiny edit or two left undone. But the book comes back into its own full force at the dramatic crescendo, where a series of tiny one-paragraph chapters spell out the unfolding of the intertwined fates of its characters. <br /> <br />There is an internal, almost symphonic logic to this work, with themes appearing and reappearing in different scenarios, in different characters throughout. In all ways masterfully done, a classic. <br />

B00000J7J4|3.0|'Supernatural' defines everything that is Carlos Santana, spirituality, peace, and mysticism. As expected, this album contains Santana's gifted latin-tinged guitarwork combined with a contemporary easy-listening feel, almost at a New Agey/jazzlike pace. The overall album dabbles in everything from strings, horns, electronic beats, bluesy solos, and guest vocalists, but if there's anything that's unmistakable, it's the breathing penetrating notes of the guitar shaman himself. The sound is that of latin wind-swept waves and the joy of living, a time of reflection, a time of introspection, a time of celebration. 'Supernatural' is not only a celebration of a guitar legend, but also a celebration of music...a celebration of life.

It is number one, a simple story when stripped of its excrescences, and number two, hypnotic from the first majestic downbeat on the soundtrack.<br /><br />The DVD looks and sounds great all the way through to the improbable and happy ending.  Of course, we have a feeling there will be trouble ahead when the little daughter of Vivica Fox grows up to brandish a weapon raised in vengeance.  Those of you who have read Cornell Woolrich's novels THE BRIDE WORE BLACK or THE BLACK ANGEL will have experienced this richness of story-telling before, but for the rest of us, KILL BILL is a novel idea, beautifully executed by a gang of pros.

B0000214F0|2.0|Lesser ecstasy, the way of all flesh, this is Caligula. Perverse, almost religious. Pretentious production overblowing the proportions of its intent, the result could have been far more meritorious and grandiose. Gore Vidal, Bob Guccione, and Tinto Brass, gathered for the ultimate erotic film ever shown in common Theaters, the result as a cinematographic triumph, not happening, but it is still shocking. The only real statement of Caligula is to have dared shown the pre-Christian Roman Empire in its entire decadent life of rotten flesh, unlimited sex, clean, filthy, orgiastic parties of special magnificence, and cut-throat acts of bestial and deprave human willing, it is great and beautiful. <br />Caligula stands somewhere in the dominions of the erotic and the graphic of pornography. Tinto Brass narrates the lousy story of Emperor Gaius Germanicus Caesar, better know as Caligula, a script by Oscar Winner writer Gore Vidal, whose intentions to tell the fall from sanity and common sense into the Necromancies of power and the corruption of its touch, corrupted by the crown and its seasons, where frustrated by Director Tinto Brass, this project was to much for him, lacking the necessary vision and talent for an accurate direction, the other layer of bad sense was indeed its producer, Bob Guccione, at least Guccione had the daring eye to show the explicit even more explicit, but also lacking the talent for a better understanding of the story, it was about sex for him since the beginning. About the Historic Caligula, the main ancient reference to the megalomaniac character (besides the vague anecdotal writings), is: Suet. Gaius; Dio 59; Philo In Flaccum and Legatio ad Gaium; Jos. AJ 19.1-211. Tacitus's account of the reign is lost. However, he makes occasional references to Gaius in the extant portions of his works, as does Seneca. The later sources inherited a tradition about Gaius that can be shown to be biased and exaggerated. Besides these literary sources, inscriptions and coins also offer some information. So you can't be factually loyal to the Historic truth, and that gives you license to do pretty much anything you want, in this matter, the film can't be criticized concerning the story of its protagonist. Tinto Brass direction is un-personal and cold, a succession of images that moves schematically towards a much predictable ending. The first 30 minutes are composed in an inappropriate Theater style, which is un-intentionally enhanced by the Theatrical production design of the settings, it seems that Tinto Brass caught a better sense of pace and composition after shooting those scenes, and some how manage a more dynamic narration, even so, without any real soul. Bob Guccione shoot additional material to be added in the sex scenes, but the mediocre editing felt short inserting those scenes in a more imperceptible way.  <br />Over the years I heard a lot of stories about the graphic and out daring ways of Caligula's sex scenes, so I expected to see real hard core images, stories that went from vast orgies, to a woman having sex with a horse, a man having intercourse with a duck, and a very long etc of perversities. So the movie didn't really shock me as I expected. Of course, if you are a very conservative or repressed person, the film will not only shock you, it will insult your moral values, Pastors, loyal Christians, and of course, Republicans, will also be severely insulted by the sex scenes, any way, the movie comes anticipated with an infamous fame, you can't make no mistakes, if you buy or rent it, don't blame the film for its controversial content, blame your self for being naive. <br />Caligula's sex content is way out dare from any previous movie that calls it self an erotic film, the difference is that Caligula does have pornographic inserts on it (plain shots of both sex's genitalia, oral sex, copulations, masturbation, etc). But the film can't be categorized as a porn flick. Pornographic movies intention is to show continuous explicit sex scenes without any real plot, always pushing for as many sex scenes as possible, Caligula doesn't have this, even though the story is poor, the sex is very well inserted in the life of the Roman Empire, expanding its plot with its main characters concerning the madness and greed for power, there is not a continuous pushing for exposure of hard core sex all over the film (at least not in the way of porn flicks), here lies the charm of the film, the sex taken in the social environment of the Roman Empire is an splendid depict of the period, every shot of sex intercourse is for free, but to be honest, I wouldn't have it any other way.  <br />The performances of the Cast are both poor and flat. Malcolm McDowell wasn't enough for the role, his malignant looks felt short, an opportunity much dismissed. The Great Peter O'toole is barely O.K. but without any resembles to his masterful and classical performances. Helen Mirren and John Gielgud are completely wasted, the rest aren't really actors to be considered so.  <br />The Woman are just beautiful, Teresa Ann Savoy (Julia Drusilla), Helen Mirren (in her younger years), as Caesonia, the Penthouse Pets are breathtaking, a real feast for the eye. <br />The photography is awful, boring colors and easy lighting, a mayor waste if you take into consideration the significant budget of the film. A good score does some goods for the film (including music by Sergei Prokofiev). Bad costume design and pretentious setting design surely captures the mood of the Roman Empire, but a fake Roman Empire. Caligula was released in 1980, at the very end of the 70's sex freedom, and just before Ronald Regan's repressed republican policies of censorship. Right now Caligula could not be shown in common Theaters in the U.S.A in its un-rated version. If it where a high pack action thriller full of blood, there will be no problem at all. <br />The DVD is O.K., the transferring can't be called bad, but a better work could have been attained, the 5.1 Dolby Digital is good, but with a poor distribution of the sounds. The Making Of Documentary is excellent and very complete (also un-rated). <br />So, even with all the bad elements in it, Caligula is brave and highly entertaining, and Cinema always needs brave and different projects to sustain it self. You can call it a piece of sh..., or a masterpiece, it doesn't matter, Caligula, Fellini Satyricon (oviously emulated by the producers of Caligula), and Gladiator are the only Roman films I'll see during Holy Weekend. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

B000000OAN|5.0|A Night At The Opera(Hollywood)(1975). Queen's Fourth Album.<br /><br />After Queen's previous three albums('Queen', 'Queen II', 'Sheer Heart Attack'), which failed to produce hardly any commercial success, their label pressured them to break through or they were going to drop them. While Queen experimented with a mixture of Hard Rock and Heavy Metal, all while adding in a Progressive touch to it, Queen didn't adapt the style everyone has known and loved over the years until 'A Night At The Opera'. While still retaining their Progressive Rock/Metal approach, Queen started using an intentionally pompous and overblown approach, making their music operatic and humorous, and adding in appealing Pop sensibilities. Apparently, Queen's purposely overblown and humorous approach to good-old Hard Rock hit off with the public, as 'A Night At The Opera' climbed the American Charts to #4, easily staying their for a long time with the #6 position of \\"The Bohemian Rhapsody\\" and the Rock Radio hit \\"You're My Best Friend\\".'A Night At The Opera' gave Queen the success they craved so much, and within the year, the album sold over a million copies, and over time has sold over 5 million, establishing it as one of their biggest successes, and etching their legend in Rock 'N Roll forever.<br /><br />As for the music, read on to find out what I thought of it!<br /><br />Track Ratings-<br /><br />Death On Two Legs(Dedicated To.....- 'A Night At The Opera' begins magnificently, as Queen molds a Gothic influenced Heavy Metal song about Vampires, entitled \\"Death On Two Legs\\". Mercury's sneering and intentionally sarcastic vocals fit perfectly with May's dark guitar melody.<br /><br />Lazing On A Sunday Afternoon- Remember Big Band and Swing? Apparently Queen does, and on \\"Lazing On A Sunday Afternoon\\", Queen has a humorous take-off of Swing, featuring Mercury's hilarious distorted vocals. Funny!<br /><br />I'm In Love With My Car- Queen hits back with \\"I'm In Love With My Car\\", a pulsing, melodic Hard Rock stunner, featuring angry vocals from Mercury, which is surprising with the cheesy subject! May throws out some killer riffs, and it's no surprise Queen delivers an excellent song here!<br /><br />You're My Best Friend- Queen's keyboard driven Pop/Rock made \\"You're My Best Friend\\" a huge hit, not to mention Mercury's operatic and soothing vocals. The backing vocals and keyboards really take this song to new heights, and \\"You're My Best Friend\\" is a short but sweet gem!<br /><br />'39- Can you imagine Queen doing Country? Neither could I! Although, after listening to \\"'39\\", I can safely say their blend of Country and Rock with Mercury's hauntingly beautiful vocals works. Typically I would slam Country Ballads, but Mercury truly makes this song excellent. Great bassline!<br /><br />Sweet Lady- \\"Sweet Lady\\" is 'A Night At The Opera's underrated masterpiece, a scathing look at women's mistreatment of their husband. Classic Hard Rock/Heavy Metal never sounded better, and Daltrey's sarcastic vocals with May's metallic assault on the ears makes \\"Sweet Lady\\" a great song! You think May's overrated? Listen to this song my friend, and his solo that's over a minute! I think you'll change your mind!<br /><br />Seaside Rendezvous- Once again, Queen experiments with Big Band and Swing, with Mercury's humorous vocals and the odd Polka instrumentation, \\"Seaside Rendezvous\\" makes for an overblown, hilarious song you can't help but like!<br /><br />The Prophet's Song- Much like Crimson King, Queen uses a Medieval Melody mixed with Progressive Metal to create an original, brilliant epic. Mercury and the backup vocalists are truly brilliant here, and their Medieval vocals and lyrics work well behind May's creative guitar harmonies. \\"The Prophet Song\\" also contains an ocappela performance by Mercury(no instruments), but soon returns to full-fledged Classic Hard Rock. Brilliant Progressive Rock, and possibly the album's masterpiece!<br /><br />Love of My Life- A Piano drivenballad, \\"Love of My Life\\" finds Mercury's brooding and operatic vocals molding a touching and moving song.<br /><br />Good Company- An odd mixture of Swing and Folk, \\"Good Company\\"'s creative and original melody, not to mention Mercury's humorous vocals make this song a winner!<br /><br />Bohemian Rhapsody- Although \\"Bohemian Rhapsody\\" charted in 1976, it never reached its peak position of #2 until 1992 after the release of 'Wayne's World', which featured the song in the most memorable scene of the movie. Featuring over 150 vocal and instrumental overdubs, \\"Bohemian Rhapsody\\" starts off as a Keyboard heavy melodic rocker, yet by the song's end, Mercury and Queen spit out some of the albums heaviest material. Overblown to the point of tedium, \\"Bohemian Rhapsody\\" is never the less a masterpiece, and one of Hard Rock's greatest songs, without a doubt!<br /><br />God Save The Queen- Brian May's take on Britain's National Anthem shows he can rip on the guitar quite well.<br /><br />The 1991 remaster of 'A Night At The Opera' features two Bonus Remixes of \\"I'm In Love With My Car\\" and \\"You're My Best Friend\\", which, while excellent, aren't really different from the originals.<br /><br />Overall, 'A Night At The Opera' is Queen's swansong, a magnificent hybrid of Heavy Metal, Hard Rock, Classic Rock, and Opera, all the while keeping that overblown and humorous aspect that fans have come to love over the years. What more can I say? Mercury, May, and the rest of Queen dish out one of the best performances of their career, and it should be heard by everyone!<br /><br />HIGHLY RECOMMENDED TO FANS OF PROG ROCK, CLASSIC ROCK, HARD ROCK, HEAVY METAL, AND QUEEN. OVERBLOWN AND POMPOUS? YES, BUT WHO EXACTLY CARES? NOT ME!<br /><br />Killer Kuts- \\"You're My Best Friend\\", \\"The Prophet's Song\\", \\"Death On Two Legs\\", and \\"Bohemian Rhapsody\\".<br /><br />Also Recommended-<br /><br />Sheer Heart Attack- Queen<br />Bat Out Of Hell- Meatloaf<br />Machine Head- Deep Purple<br /><br />Thanks For Reading!moving song.    Good Company- An odd mixture of Swing and Folk, \\"Good Company\\"'s creative and original melody, not to mention Mercury's humorous vocals make this song a winner!    Bohemian Rhapsody- Although \\"Bohemian Rhapsody\\" charted in 1976, it never reached its peak position of #2 until 1992 after the release of 'Wayne's World', which featured the song in the most memorable scene of the movie. Featuring over 150 vocal and instrumental overdubs, \\"Bohemian Rhapsody\\" starts off as a Keyboard heavy melodic rocker, yet by the song's end, Mercury and Queen spit out some of the albums heaviest material. Overblown to the point of tedium, \\"Bohemian Rhapsody\\" is never the less a masterpiece, and one of Hard Rock's greatest songs, without a doubt!    God Save The Queen- Brian May's take on Britain's National Anthem shows he can rip on the guitar quite well.    The 1991 remaster of 'A Night At The Opera' features two Bonus Remixes of \\"I'm In Love With My Car\\" and \\"You're My Best Friend\\", which, while excellent, aren't really different from the originals.    Overall, 'A Night At The Opera' is Queen's swansong, a magnificent hybrid of Heavy Metal, Hard Rock, Classic Rock, and Opera, all the while keeping that overblown and humorous aspect that fans have come to love over the years. What more can I say? Mercury, May, and the rest of Queen dish out one of the best performances of their career, and it should be heard by everyone! Also Recommended-    Sheer Heart Attack- Queen  Bat Out Of Hell- Meatloaf  Machine Head- Deep Purple    Thanks For Reading!

0451191153|4.0|An interesting book that comes close to championing the value of common sense,  but unfortunately veers into unresolvable philosophical issues. But I guess for an argument to be considered \\"philosophical\\" it has to worship idealogy over boring old reality. At least Rand had more common sense than the Buddhist reviewer.  He, as I once did, values idealogy over his own experience. One doesn't really face the \\"truth\\" that there is no self unless one is sitting around reading a book about it.  This philosophy pretends to embrace the transitoriness of life and thus paints itself as brave in the face of harsh realities, but in fact it is merely and intellectual fantasy. It pretends not to be intellectual but is really hyperintellectual: it places its own idealogy above the basic instincts, feelings, senses, and desires of humankind. I talk too much of this because I have experienced it, and I believe deeply that it is a sickness.  Sometimes religion can certainly be healthy, and I am sure there are plenty of positive aspects of buddhism, but any philosophy which tells you that caring for yourself is merely caring for an \\"illusion\\" and that valuing and cherishing your own desires and aspirations (assuming they are healthy, etc.) is a sin is essentially the cruelest form of masochism in a kind, gentle cloak.  Whatever you think it will do for you in terms of happiness and mental health, please rethink it.  It is an easy trap to fall in for idealistic people, and I speak from experience. Anyway, if anyone has any comments I'd like to hear them.

0393307050|5.0|First, let me say that this review is really more about the entire Aubrey-Maturn series than this particular book. But it really must be so; you would be missing out on a fantastic experience if you read only this first book. You wouldn't read just the first book of The Lord of the Rings, would you? Then don't even consider just reading this book without reading at least a few others in the series (this is really just a clever subterfuge on my part; once you read 2 or 3 of the books, you won't be able to stop until you've read the entire series!).   <br /> <br />There are lots of literary niches, or genres. Spy novels, horror novels, romances, detective stories, etc. It would be damning this series with faint praise to extol it simply in terms of it being about naval warfare in the early 1800's.  <br /> <br />In fact, when I first saw this series (an intimidating 20 volumes), I thought \\"how many ways are there of describing a broadside?\\" Oh, how little I knew... <br /> <br />It's true that this series features rollicking adventure, but it includes so much more: a deep, complex relationship between the two main characters, political intrigue, espionage, and so much more. It is so much richer and more wonderfully complex even than Forester's much-beloved Horatio Hornblower series.  <br /> <br />Some authors find success with a particular style of book, and basically crank out volume after volume of basically the same story. How ironic it is, then, that in this long series featuring the same characters that there is such variety! <br /> <br />One warning: there is a lot of naval jargon in the books. It can be off-putting at first, but don't let it discourage you. It is really just the \\"background noise\\" of the story, much like the legal jargon in a courtroom drama. That said, I strongly recommend the purchase of \\"A Sea of Words\\" by Dean King as a companion book. I have found that it enhanced my enjoyment of this series.  <br /> <br />Be warned: after experiencing the incredible character development, rich detail, and brilliant plots of this series, you will be less tolerant of much of the drivel that passes for good writing nowadays. <br /> <br />One final comment: even if O'Brian had simply made up the historical events and details of daily shipboard life, it would be a terrific read. The fact that he did painstaking research worthy of a world-class historian, and that he often dropped his fictional characters smack-dab in the middle of historically accurate events just adds an extral layer of amazement and wonder to my appreciation of these superb stories.

B00007KWHO|3.0|Magnification this isn't, but all in all, Time And A Word isn't a bad album.  But I'm sure that if Yes had it to do over again, there would be absolutely no orchestra interfering with the music here.<br /><br />It ruins a lot of perfectly good moments, most notably \\"The Prophet,\\" an otherwise enjoyable song that is made nearly unlistenable with the ugly orchestration poking its head in.  The same applies to \\"Then.\\"  \\"Clear Days\\" is up there with \\"Circus Of Heaven\\" and \\"The Ancient\\" as Yes songs so bad they make me want to gag- the string section on this song sounds so completely ridiculous and out of place.  Even Jon Anderson's lovely vocal delivery doesn't redeem it much.<br /><br />The opening piece, \\"No Opportunity Necessary, No Experience Needed,\\" is the only song featuring the orchestra that isn't dragged down by it; indeed, it actually adds a touch of drama to the song.  In fact, it kind of sounds a little overdramatic, almost ironic, but maybe I'm reading too much into it.<br /><br />It's no surprise that two of the best songs on Time And A Word are the only two that don't feature the orchestra- \\"Sweet Dreams\\" and \\"Astral Traveller.\\"  \\"Sweet Dreams\\" is a fun and light song that sounds like something off of Rubber Soul (but then again, a lot of the songs on the first two Yes albums sound like The Beatles).  \\"Astral Traveller,\\" the best song on the album, is a dark and moody piece that features heavy organ work from Tony Kaye- he dominates the entire album, but he really shines on this song.  I like the big, unexpected rock `n' roll finish.<br /><br />The title track, which closes the album, doesn't feature the orchestra prominently, and it's a harmless, contagious little song.  \\"There's a time, and the time is now and it's right for me, and the time is now, there's a word, and the word is love and it's right for me-\\" trust me, you won't be able to get it out of your head.<br /><br />If you want Yes with a symphony orchestra, Magnification is the way to go, but overall, Time And A Word is worth listening to for all that the orchestra didn't ruin.way to go, but overall, Time And A Word is worth listening to for all that the orchestra didn't ruin.

B00005JNEI|4.0|Michael Moore himself says that he made this film specifically to get George W. Bush out of office.  Of course, he also is out to make money.  No one can deny that this movie really cashed in on the latter goal. <br /> <br />With regards to the first goal, this film does an excellent job.  Rarely is the most effective way to gain votes for a particular candidate to actually cater to undecideds by rationally convincing them to vote for the desired candidate.  Rather, it's to energize those that already support the candidate in question to actually get out and vote.  As such, the movie does an excellent job energzing Kerry Supporters to get angry enough at Bush to vote, and in some cases, actually get involved in the campaign.   <br /> <br />Ifyou're an undecided voter looking for rational guidance, this movie is clearly not for you.  No one that either already likes Bush or is undecided is going to see anything compelling here -- far too much of the movie is intentionally biased and overtly presented in a way as to deliberately make Bush look worse than he deserves (which is quite an accomplishment, since he is quite adept at making himself look terrible without any outside help).  This movie is quite humorous in the process, so it definitely earns high marks as a fun way to spend a couple of hours.  However, it earns poor marks for actual informational value -- which is of concern in a movie that bills itself as a documentary, and why I docked it a star.  This movie will make Kerry supporters mad enough that they'll be more likely to vote, but won't actually cause anyone to learn anything they didn't already know or believe anything they didn't already believe. <br /> <br />See this movie cause it's fun, and, if you're liberal, to get energized.  Don't see it to get any sort of decent political content.

B000000HU0|4.0|1974's You had showed Gong at their peak, closing off the Radio Gnome trilogy with what had to be their finest album. Daevid Allen, Gilli Smyth, and Tim Blake had all left the band after that album. Steve Hillage got to work on his first solo album, Fish Rising (which basically featured all the Gong members, plus Dave Stewart and Lindsay Cooper, minus of course, Allen). That left Gong with Didier Malherbe, Pierre Moerlen, Mike Howlett, and Mireille Bauer. Vocal duties were now handled by Howlett, and they decided to add a Frenchman by the name of Patrice Lemoine to handle the keyboards. Lemoine was obviously a much more conventional keyboardist than Tim Blake, so no fancy VCS-3 synth bubbles and spacy Moog leads. Instead he went for a Fender Rhodes electric piano and a Mini Moog played more in the fusion manner. Without Daevid Allen anymore, it's no surprise that stories of the Planet Gong and Pot Head Pixies were absent, but the lyrics often still remained quirky, especially \\"Wingful of Eye\\". Some of the songs on this album have a rather strong ethnic bent to them, especially \\"Bambooji\\". \\"Chandra\\" shows the band at their more fusion-oriented side. \\"Cat in Clark's Shoe\\" is a rather quirky number, gets a little cheesy in places, especially when you have an Argentine by the name of Jorge Pinchevesky provide some violin. He was a guest on the album and apparently a fixture in Argentina's music scene. Steve Hillage is now pretty much credited as a guest on this album, as he'd be going solo full time after this album. Shamal shows that Gong was still able to make some great music without the presence of the Pot Head Pixie crew. Unfortunately, for me, I felt the band moved to more conventional fusion after this album that didn't do much for me. But for Shamal, it's still another recommended album if you like Gong, although of course, I prefer You.

If you simply look over the lyrics, Radiohead's power will become apparent. <br />Unlike other bands, Radiohead makes you wait for lead singer Thom Yorke to voice any of his poetry, pulling you along with amazing melodies. B000LE16VW|4.0|I have loved the movie Ghost since I was a little girl, and I first taped it off the TV. How sad. But even now, with the special edition DVD, and the fact that I'm now in my twenties, doesn't make watching the \\"two deaths\\"/shadow demons bit any easier. That totally freaked me out as a kid, and even now, I had to turn away, even the sound sent shivers up my spine. Apparently, the sound is babies screaming, but slowed down. Ugh. I've progressed from hiding behind the couch, to hiding behind a cushion, to turning my face away, and closing my eyes. My aren't I growing up.<br /><br />Ghost is definitely a classic of the nineties, and I can't believe so many actors turned down the role of Sam Wheat, because they felt it wouldn't work. Even the director thought Patrick Swayze wasn't right for the role, and has famously said (and denies it) that he would have Patrick for the role \\"over his dead body\\".<br /><br />Ghost stories can sometimes be overdone in the world of film, but this is done with some sensitivity, and also from the ghost's point of view. Doesn't make me any keener on Demi Moore's hairstyle in this.  The only hairstyle worse than this is the one she sported in GI Jane. Not a good look. I have to disagree with other reviewers that say this is a great date movie. It's not. I wouldn't even dream of even asking my boyfriend to watch this with me. Probably cos he wouldn't like it, and would hate every minute of it. But we can't all like the same stuff.<br /><br />I did have a few problems with one of the extras on this DVD though. I just re-read my old Amazon review and here's what I originally said about the extras: \\"There's a lack of extras on this DVD, apart from a trailer, a commentary, and \\"interviews with the cast\\" - which is basically re-showing the whole movie all over again! Think of the most boring extras ever, and bam, there they are on the Ghost DVD. Please, use your imagination for once.\\"<br /><br />They have taken my advice (why wouldn't they?), the extras are short & sweet, but I think the same featurette from the first edition is on the first disc of this edition, which isn't too bad. But then I put on the second disc, watched the first featurette - and it's almost word perfect, clip perfect of the same featurette, just a couple of years on. And I'm very disappointed that the interview with Demi Moore is a very old interview. Patrick, and the director, and the screenwriter came back for new interviews, but hers is old.<br /><br />All the actors do a brilliant job, but I did feel the whole storyline with Carl, Sam's best friend, and his girlfriend, Molly, (where he pours coffee over himself and removes his shirt to show off his physique) was unnecessary. And it didn't quite work with the tone of the rest of the film either. Tony Goldwyn did an alright role, but that whole segment for me just didn't feel right. As if the audience would believe Molly would go with Carl, who was Sam's best friend, just after he'd died.<br /><br />The major scene stealer in this film, who quite rightly should have had more screen time, was the late great Vincent Schiavelli, who died from lung cancer at the end of 2005. He was one of the great character actors, and although he was simply credited in this as Subway Ghost, he stole the show from Patrick, and was just amazing. He's well missed. If I mention Vincent Schiavelli, I also have to mention the actor who played Willie Lopez, Rick Aviles. He also sadly died in 1995, from AIDS.<br /><br />What I think would have made this film work even more, is if Molly had found out she was pregnant with Sam's baby. But is that too much? I think it would have made the ending so sweet if she'd told him she was pregnant. But then it could have sent it into OTT schmaltzy. But what pregnancy wouldn't be good in a film?<br /><br />I absolutely LOVE the score to this film, and that's something coming from me, cos I often have trouble with scores on films.
